title: 2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony
text:
The <a href="Olympic%20Games%20ceremony%23Opening">opening ceremony</a> of the <a href="2010%20Winter%20Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a> was held on February 12, 2010, beginning at 6:00 pm <a href="Pacific%20Time%20Zone">PST</a> (02:00 <a href="UTC">UTC</a>, February 13) at <a href="BC%20Place%20Stadium">BC Place Stadium</a> in <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>, <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. This was the first Olympic opening ceremony to be held indoors. It was directed by <a href="David%20Atkins">David Atkins</a>.
The event was officially opened by <a href="Micha%C3%ABlle%20Jean">Michaëlle Jean</a>, <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">Governor General of Canada</a>, the representative of <a href="Elizabeth%20II">Elizabeth II</a>, <a href="Monarchy%20of%20Canada">Queen of Canada</a>. The opening ceremony was dedicated by the <a href="Vancouver%20Organizing%20Committee%20for%20the%202010%20Olympic%20and%20Paralympic%20Winter%20Games">Vancouver Organizing Committee</a> (VANOC) to <a href="Nodar%20Kumaritashvili">Nodar Kumaritashvili</a>, a Georgian <a href="luge">luge</a>r who had died earlier in the day in a training run. An audience of 61,600 was in attendance at the venue, and there were an estimated 4,500 performers.
Production.
The production's director was <a href="David%20Atkins">David Atkins</a>, who directed the <a href="2000%20Summer%20Olympics%20opening%20ceremony">Sydney 2000 Olympic</a> and <a href="2006%20Asian%20Games">2006 Doha Asian Games</a> ceremonies. The Opening and Closing Ceremonies had a combined budget of $48.5 million (it received $20 million () funding from the <a href="Department%20of%20Canadian%20Heritage">Department of Canadian Heritage</a> while VANOC contributed the rest). Much of the instrumental music for the ceremony was written by <a href="Dave%20Pierce">Dave Pierce</a>, <a href="Gavin%20Greenaway">Gavin Greenaway</a>, and <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110716031512/http%3A//www.cpo-live.com/main/biography.php%3Fid%3D12">Donovan Seidle</a>.
The music during the ceremony came from the live on-stage orchestra, conducted by Pierce.
On December 15, 2010, <a href="John%20Furlong%20%28sports%20administrator%29">John Furlong</a>, the CEO of VANOC revealed that <a href="Celine%20Dion">Celine Dion</a> had been contracted to sing the national anthem at the Opening Ceremony. However, when she became pregnant she cancelled the performance and was subsequently replaced by 16-year-old <a href="Nikki%20Yanofsky">Nikki Yanofsky</a>. In addition, Furlong also revealed that "a famous Quebec composer" was contracted to provide musical elements to the show. That composer, whom he would not name, backed out of arrangement months before the Games over what he termed "philosophical differences." As a result, the artist refused to allow VANOC access to his music's rights and the organizing committee had to unwind part of the ceremony. There is speculation within the media that the Opening Ceremony's cultural show finale titled "We Are More," featuring slam poetry by <a href="Shane%20Koyczan">Shane Koyczan</a>, served as a last minute replacement for the canceled segment featuring the Quebec composer's music. VANOC had also requested the <a href="Cirque%20du%20Soleil">Cirque du Soleil</a> to perform several aerial stunts, however it opted not to as it was already stretched with many U.S. productions.
Program.
Dedication.
At 5:59 (<a href="Pacific%20Standard%20Time">PST</a>), a <a href="Public%20address">PA system</a> announced that the opening ceremony would be dedicated in memory of the <a href="Georgia%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics">Georgian</a> <a href="luge">luge</a>r <a href="Nodar%20Kumaritashvili">Nodar Kumaritashvili</a>, who had died in a training accident earlier that day.
Opening section.
Giant video screens showed Canadian <a href="snowboarder">snowboarder</a> Johnny Lyall sliding down a mountain slope, with the dates and locations of previous Winter Olympic games were recalled in voiceover. As the 1988 games in Calgary were mentioned, Lyall passed through a row of torchbearers in the shape of the Canadian symbol: the <a href="maple%20leaf">maple leaf</a>. This concluded with Lyall leaping through a set of <a href="Olympic%20Rings">Olympic Rings</a>, while snow and ice exploded off them and into the stadium, and him welcoming the crowd.
National anthem.
A guard of honour mounted by the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Mounted%20Police">RCMP</a> marched the <a href="Flag%20of%20Canada">Canadian Flag</a> to the flagpost. There a guard of honour composed of <a href="Canadian%20Forces">Canadian Forces</a> members raised the flag. <a href="Nikki%20Yanofsky">Nikki Yanofsky</a> performed an arrangement of the national anthem, "<a href="O%20Canada">O Canada</a>", singing in English and French.
Welcome by the Aboriginal Peoples of Canada.
The <a href="First%20Nations%20in%20Canada">First Nations</a> in whose traditional territories the games were held - the <a href="Squamish%20Nation">Squamish Nation</a>, <a href="Musqueam%20Indian%20Band">Musqueam Indian Band</a>, <a href="Lil%27wat%20First%20Nation">Lil'wat First Nation</a>, and <a href="Tsleil-Waututh%20First%20Nation">Tsleil-Waututh First Nation</a> - were recognized as heads of state and seated directly behind the Canadian Governor General and the Prime Minister. Four Coast Salish welcome poles were raised from the centre of the stadium, and greetings were given to the crowd (and the world) by members of the Four Host First Nations in their respective languages as well as English and French. The arms of the poles were raised in a traditional gesture of greeting to welcome the athletes and the world. Following the greetings, groups of dancers from other main culture-regions of <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20in%20Canada">Indigenous peoples in Canada</a> were introduced, including the <a href="M%C3%A9tis%20in%20Canada">Métis Nation</a> and the <a href="Inuit">Inuit</a>, as well as the Peoples of the Northwest, the Peoples of the Plains and the Peoples of the East and took places around the welcome poles and a large drum surface between them, forming a welcome circle to prepare for the forthcoming Parade of the Nations and danced traditional welcoming dances as the athletes paraded in.
Parade of the Nations.
The participating countries marched in, with <a href="Greece%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics">Greece</a> coming first, then the other nations ending with the host nation, <a href="Canada%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics">Canada</a>. The names of the nations were announced first in French and followed by English, the official languages of the Olympics, which also happened to be the official languages of the host nation. The nations entered in alphabetic order of their country names in English because it is the more dominant of the two languages in Vancouver and in the province of British Columbia.
The team from <a href="Georgia%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics">Georgia</a> was greeted with a standing ovation out of respect for their colleague, <a href="Nodar%20Kumaritashvili">Nodar Kumaritashvili</a>, who died in a luge accident earlier that day. The team left an empty space in the processional and left the stadium immediately following the procession. They had indicated they would not participate in the opening ceremony or withdraw completely, but decided against doing so. The team wore black scarves and armbands to honor Kumaritashvili while a black ribbon was affixed to the team's flag. Teams from some countries, including <a href="Australia%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics">Australia</a>, <a href="Azerbaijan%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics">Azerbaijan</a> also wore black armbands in respect of Kumaritashvili.
The <a href="United%20States%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics">United States</a>, received one of the loudest ovations before Canada entered two minutes later.
Athlete Tribute Song.
<a href="Nelly%20Furtado">Nelly Furtado</a> and <a href="Bryan%20Adams">Bryan Adams</a>, both themselves Vancouver residents performed "Bang the Drum", which was written by Adams and producer <a href="Jim%20Vallance">Jim Vallance</a> as a tribute to the Olympic athletes present.
The Landscape of a Dream.
The cultural section of the Opening Ceremony was titled "The Landscape of a Dream" whose purpose was to celebrate the diverse geography and people of Canada. It was directed by <a href="David%20Atkins">David Atkins</a> and the narration was provided by <a href="Donald%20Sutherland">Donald Sutherland</a>, himself one of the Olympic flag bearers. It featured tributes to different regions of Canada.
Hymns of the North.
A Tribute to <a href="Northern%20Canada">Northern Canada</a> After Nelly Furtado and Bryan Adams had finished their performance, snow began to fall throughout the stadium. Performers, dressed in warm, Inuit-like clothes, walked about and mingled on the stage floor. Their leader took his staff and banged it on the ground, producing waves of light rippling on the floor. The northern lights and different constellations of animals appeared. A giant, sparkling puppet (one of the largest puppets ever created) of a spirit or <a href="Kermode%20bear">Kermode bear</a> that rose from the stadium floor, and hovered over the performers, who were standing on a simulated ice floe. After a few seconds, the ice began to break up, and the performers "floated" to the edge of the stage, where they disappeared. The ice breaking away gave way to a huge arctic sea, where simulated whales swam while breathing until next transition.
Rhythms of the Fall.
This tribute to the fiddling traditions of Canada paying homage to the <a href="Anglo-Celtic">Anglo-Celtic</a> roots of European Canadian settler culture began with the appearance of the horned fiddler in a flying canoe, a reference to the story of the <a href="Chasse-galerie">Chasse-galerie</a>, where the Devil rode a magical canoe. As the canoe descended from the ceiling, the opening of the song "The Old Ways" was performed by <a href="Loreena%20McKennitt">Loreena McKennitt</a>.
Who Has Seen the Wind.
"Who Has Seen the Wind" was a tribute to Canadian Prairies. A lone boy, Thomas Saulgrain (L'École Nationale de Cirque) stood in the centre of the floor in a square wheat. A voice quoted from the novel <a href="Who%20Has%20Seen%20the%20Wind%20%28novel%29">Who Has Seen the Wind (novel)</a> by <a href="W.%20O.%20Mitchell">W. O. Mitchell</a> As the boy began running, he was lifted up and performed ballet on fly wire. A rendition of the song "<a href="Both%20Sides%2C%20Now%20%28song%29">Both Sides, Now</a>" by <a href="Joni%20Mitchell">Joni Mitchell</a> was played during this segment.
Peaks of Endeavour.
"Peaks of Endeavour" was a tribute to the Canadian Rockies and Western Canada. After the previous segment had ended, a storm was stimulated and clouds seemed to fall to the ground. As the clouds gave away, mountains, resembling the Rocky Mountains, rose from the floor. A <a href="George%20Vancouver">George Vancouver</a> quote was read by Donald Sutherland, and skiers and snowboarders hung from wires to simulate going down the artificial mountains. Images of winter sports in action exploded onto the mountains, which finally gave way to sports victories. Inline skaters mimicked figure skaters and speed skaters, circling the artificial mountains as the videos of sports changed to the Vancouver skyline. Coloured lines of light representing flowing traffic surrounded the mountain.
We Are More.
After the mountains that had been the feature for "Peaks of Endeavor" fell away, <a href="Shane%20Koyczan">Shane Koyczan</a> performed <a href="slam%20poetry">slam poetry</a>, a variation on his <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20070928180825/http%3A//surveys.canada.travel/ca/en_ca/media/en_ca/demo.mp3">"We Are More"</a>. (<a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20100324054154/http%3A//www.vancouversun.com/news/More%2BTranscript%2Bopening%2Bceremony%2Bpoem%2BShane%2BKoyczan/2558526/story.html">transcript</a>)
Performers formed a giant maple leaf around Koyczan with red flares to end off his section.
Opening remarks/Official Opening.
The opening remarks began with <a href="Jacques%20Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a>, President of the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">IOC</a>, who offered sympathy for the loss of Georgian luge athlete, <a href="Nodar%20Kumaritashvili">Nodar Kumaritashvili</a>. A welcome from <a href="John%20Furlong%20%28Canadian%29">John Furlong</a>, Chair of <a href="Vancouver%20Organizing%20Committee%20for%20the%202010%20Olympic%20and%20Paralympic%20Winter%20Games">the Vancouver Organizing Committee</a>, was then delivered. (<a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20100215185929/http%3A//www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-spectator-guide/celebrations-and-ceremonies/ceremonies/opening-ceremonies/opening-ceremonies---john-furlong_274284dm.html">transcript</a>) A statement by Rogge followed, mixing English and French. Finally, <a href="Micha%C3%ABlle%20Jean">Michaëlle Jean</a>, <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">Governor General of Canada</a>, declared the games officially open, first in French, then in English.
Song of Peace.
<a href="k.d.%20lang">k.d. lang</a> performed a version of <a href="Leonard%20Cohen">Leonard Cohen</a>'s "<a href="Hallelujah%20%28Leonard%20Cohen%20song%29">Hallelujah</a>". While she was singing, <a href="doves">doves</a>, the <a href="symbol%20of%20peace">symbol of peace</a>, were projected on the stage floor, and rose from the stage floor to the ceiling via columns to symbolize their release.
Entry of the Olympic Flag.
Former hockey star <a href="Bobby%20Orr">Bobby Orr</a>; musician <a href="Anne%20Murray">Anne Murray</a>; <a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a> champion <a href="Jacques%20Villeneuve">Jacques Villeneuve</a>; <a href="Betty%20Fox">Betty Fox</a>, the mother of cancer research champion <a href="Terry%20Fox">Terry Fox</a>; actor <a href="Donald%20Sutherland">Donald Sutherland</a>; gold medal figure skater <a href="Barbara%20Ann%20Scott">Barbara Ann Scott</a>; <a href="UNAMIR">UNAMIR</a> commander <a href="Rom%C3%A9o%20Dallaire">Roméo Dallaire</a>; and <a href="Julie%20Payette">Julie Payette</a>, Canadian astronaut, carried the <a href="Olympic%20flag">flag</a> into the stadium. They then transferred the flag to members of the RCMP, who then raised the flag. Canadian <a href="opera">opera</a> singer <a href="Measha%20Brueggergosman">Measha Brueggergosman</a> sang the <a href="Olympic%20Hymn">Olympic Hymn</a>, mixing English and French.
Afterwards, a minute of silence was observed for the Georgian luger <a href="Nodar%20Kumaritashvili">Nodar Kumaritashvili</a>'s death, during which time both the Canadian and Olympic flags were lowered to <a href="half-mast">half-mast</a>. Upon learning of Kumaritashvili's death, the <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">Governor General of Canada</a>-<a href="Queen-in-Council">in-Council</a> ordered flags on <a href="Government%20of%20Canada">federal government</a> buildings throughout the province of British Columbia, including at all Olympic venues, flown at half-mast until midnight, February 13, 2010.
Olympic Oaths.
Canadian woman's <a href="ice%20hockey">ice hockey</a> player <a href="Hayley%20Wickenheiser">Hayley Wickenheiser</a> took the oath on behalf of all 2010 Olympic athletes in English, while the officials' oath was taken by <a href="short%20track%20speed%20skating">short track speed skating</a> referee <a href="Michel%20Verrault">Michel Verrault</a> in French.
Song.
<a href="Garou%20%28singer%29">Garou</a> sang "Un peu plus haut, un peu plus loin" (A Little Higher, A Little Further), written by <a href="Jean-Pierre%20Ferland">Jean-Pierre Ferland</a>.
Lighting of the Cauldron.
<a href="Rick%20Hansen">Rick Hansen</a>, paraplegic athlete and paralympic medalist, carried the flame into BC Place stadium and lit the torch of speed skater <a href="Catriona%20Le%20May%20Doan">Catriona Le May Doan</a>, who in turn lit the torch of basketball All-Star <a href="Steve%20Nash">Steve Nash</a>. Nash then lit skier <a href="Nancy%20Greene">Nancy Greene</a>'s torch who lit the torch of <a href="Wayne%20Gretzky">Wayne Gretzky</a>, <a href="Hockey%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Hall of Fame</a> hockey player. Le May Doan, Nash, Greene, and Gretzky then made their way to their four pre-determined locations on the stadium floor to await the raising of the cauldron. Due to a malfunction of the Olympic cauldron's <a href="Hydraulic%20machinery">hydraulic</a> system, only three of the four arms came up before it was lit. Le May Doan's designated arm of the cauldron had malfunctioned, so she stood by as the other three athletes lit the cauldron at the same time by touching the base of the arms with their respective torches.
Under IOC rules, the lighting of the Olympic cauldron must be witnessed by those attending the opening ceremony, implying that it must be lit at the location where the ceremony is taking place. Although another IOC rule states that the cauldron should be witnessed outside by the entire residents of the entire host city, this was not possible since the ceremony took place indoors. However, VANOC secretly built a second outdoor cauldron next to the West Building of the <a href="Vancouver%20Convention%20Centre">Vancouver Convention Centre</a>, and Gretzky was secretly chosen to light this permanent cauldron. Quickly word spread through the downtown Vancouver area that Gretzky was indeed the final torchbearer, and very soon a crush of people came running after the police escort to cheer Gretzky on and hopefully catch a glimpse of him carrying the torch to the outdoor cauldron.
The <a href="2010%20Winter%20Olympics%20closing%20ceremony">closing ceremony</a> of the games would begin with a tongue-in-cheek homage to the indoor cauldron malfunction, featuring mime Yves Dagenais repairing and finally raising the missing arm of the cauldron, and offering Le May Doan a chance to finally light her arm of the interior cauldron.
Reception.
Bilingualism.
<a href="James%20Moore%20%28Canadian%20politician%29">James Moore</a>, the <a href="Minister%20of%20Canadian%20Heritage">Minister of Canadian Heritage</a>, and Quebec Premier <a href="Jean%20Charest">Jean Charest</a> both expressed disappointment in the limited amount of French content during the ceremony. The Canadian <a href="Office%20of%20the%20Commissioner%20of%20Official%20Languages">Commissioner of Official Languages</a>, <a href="Graham%20Fraser">Graham Fraser</a>, was of the impression that the event was "developed, perceived and presented in English with a French song." Fraser's office received numerous complaints regarding the ceremony. VANOC, however, defended the case and said that they had made "a very deliberate focus and effort to ensure a strong celebration of Quebec culture and language." They also said that there was a significant amount of French in the opening ceremony. <a href="David%20Atkins">David Atkins</a> said that the ceremonies did celebrate francophone Canada.
Multiculturalism.
There are critics saying that 41% of Metro Vancouver residents are visible minorities yet these groups are mostly absent from the opening ceremony. VANOC CEO <a href="John%20Furlong%20%28Canadian%29">John Furlong</a> hints that VANOC would try to address this issue in the closing ceremony.
Television.
The international television audience varied from source. VANOC estimated more than a billion watched the ceremony.
North American ratings.
On both sides of the <a href="Canada%E2%80%93United%20States%20border">Canada-US border</a>, this opening ceremony drew high television ratings.
In Canada, this ceremony aired on the <a href="CTV%20Television%20Network">CTV Television Network</a> and 10 other channels (all part of a <a href="Canada%27s%20Olympic%20Broadcast%20Media%20Consortium">CTV-Rogers media consortium</a>), in a total of 11 languages. The broadcast drew an average of 13.3 million viewers across the country at any given moment, and 23 million Canadians, 69 percent of the national audience, watching at least a portion of the 3.5-hour ceremony. It was, for a period, the most-watched television event in Canadian history; these numbers were surpassed on the final day of the Games by the <a href="Ice%20hockey%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament%23Gold%20medal%20game">gold medal game of the Men's hockey tournament</a>, which drew 16.6 million viewers.
South of the border, <a href="Olympics%20on%20NBC">NBC</a> reported an average of 32.6 million viewers, making it the second-most watched non-United States Winter Olympics, behind the <a href="1994%20Winter%20Olympics">Lillehammer Games in 1994</a>, which drew 33.8 million, and the third most-watched non-United States Olympics, behind the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics%20opening%20ceremony">previous one</a>, the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics in Beijing two years before</a> (34.2 million) and Lillehammer, and with 67.5 million viewers watching at least a portion of it, it was the most watched non-United States Winter Olympics, and the second-most watched non-United States Olympics, behind Beijing, as that drew 69.9 million viewers.
Soundtrack.
A soundtrack, Sounds of Vancouver 2010: Opening Ceremony Commemorative Album (), was released through the <a href="iTunes%20Store">iTunes Store</a> on February 12, 2010, containing many studio recordings of the performances from the opening ceremony. It charted at #6 on the <a href="Canadian%20Albums%20Chart">Canadian Albums Chart</a>, and has sold over 50,000 copies. The song performed by <a href="Garou%20%28singer%29">Garou</a>, "Un peu plus haut, un peu plus loin (A little higher, a little further)", was released on the accompanying soundtrack for the closing ceremony.
